questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about indexes and their administration in an Oracle database? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABE
C and F are wrong, oracle documentation says:
Unlike unusable indexes, an invisible index is maintained during DML statements.
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/admin/managing-indexes.html#GUID-3A66938F-73C6-4173-844E-3938A0DBBB54

Selected Answer: ABE
ABE correct

Selected Answer: ABE
ABE correct
BEF for me

Selected Answer: ABE
These are correct

Selected Answer: ABE
invisible indexes are maintained, unusable indexes are not. C and F are wrong

F is wrong but C is correct:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/server.112/e17120/indexes004.htm
so either ACE or BCE

comments.content: C is false, it is explained on the link you provided on the section: Understand When to Use Unusable or Invisible Indexes

discussion.content: F is wrong. it is not maintained by DML.
ABE are correct

Answer is ABE.
F is wrong, unused index is not mentained

choices.E: An index can be created as part of a CREATE TABLE statement.
choices.A: The same table column can be part of a unique and non-unique index.
choices.B: A descending index is a type of function-based index.
choices.F: An UNUSABLE index is maintained when DML is performed on its underlying table.
choices.D: If a query filters on an indexed column then it will always be used during execution of the query.
choices.C: An INVINSIBLE index is not maintained when DML is performed on its underlying table.

discussion.content: Answer D, since in GROUP BY clause must used column names instead positioned numbers like here, like GROUP BY deptno - works fine

D 
ORA-00979: not a GROUP BY expression
why D? A is correct

comments.content: Because the Group by requires all items in the select clause
Correction: One can order by 1 but you have to name the group by columns

choices.C: all departments and a sum of the salaries of employees with a salary greater than 3000
choices.A: only departments where the total salary is greater than 3000, returned in no particular order
choices.B: only departments where the total salary is greater than 3000, ordered by department

questions.question_text: Which two are true about virtual columns? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Correct answer is: AB
A. Virtual columns can be indexed just like regular columns. This is useful when queries frequently filter or sort data based on the virtual column, as indexing improves performance.

B. Virtual columns can be used in the expression of another virtual column. This allows for more complex derived data to be generated from other columns, including other virtual columns.

E is false. Although virtual columns can be used in a WHERE clause of queries to filter data, they cannot be used in the WHERE clause of an UPDATE or DELETE statement because these statements modify data, and virtual columns are not physically stored.

Selected Answer: AE
AE They can be indexed and used in where clause of UPDATE and DELETE statements
https://oracle-base.com/articles/11g/virtual-columns-11gr1

Selected Answer: AE
more details about virtual columns: https://www.gpsos.es/2021/03/virtual-columns-in-oracle-use-and-limitations/?lang=en

choices.D: They can be referenced in the set clause of an update statement as the name of the column to be updated.
choices.C: They cannot have a data type explicitly specified.
choices.B: They can be referenced in the column expression of another virtual column.
choices.E: They can be referenced in the where clause of an update or delete statement.
